explanation:
Correct calculation: \(130\% \times 40 = 1.3 \times 40 = 52\).  
Student's calculation: \(130\% \times 40 = 0.3 \times 40 = 12\).  

The student treated the full percentage value (130%) as if only the excess over 100% (30%) was relevant. This stems from interpreting percentages greater than 100% as instructions to use only the portion exceeding the "whole," rather than recognizing that 130% represents scaling by 1.3.  

The error directly connects to misunderstanding percentages beyond 100%: the student subtracted 100% implicitly and applied the remaining 30% alone. This differs from misreading digit positions (which would require misparsing "130" as "30") or general multiplication errors. The flaw lies specifically in failing to process the full percentage as a unified multiplier.
